posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56762511
If you want high quality prints that will mostly will be determined by the material you use. For a beginner is better to get something like an Ender 3 V2 (theres a NEO version now) or something like the Biqu B1, its kinda of a better, more modern Ender 3 but it's not from Creality, otherwise you can get a Creality S1 which has a direct drive style extrusion and its super easy to assemble, but you wont be able to print superfast like a bowden style extruder, yet I doubt you will do that anyways.

As for materials, eSun PLA+ is what I would recommend hands down for /k/ related stuff, dont buy Creality PLA, it sucks and eSun usually cheaper too. TPU which is a flexible material, if you find it from Creality, you can go ahead, Creality TPU is actually pretty decent.
For high end resistant materials, you can get either ABS/ABS+ which is great, but its a pain in the ass to print since its VERY prone to temperature change, so you most likely would have to build an enclosure for your printer to keep it all warm, otherwise the print will deform with just room temperature due of material retraction. PETG is basically the better version of ABS since its just as resistant but its kinda similar to PLA+ but just needs the higher temperature to print, but its not very affected by temperature and material retraction, so for parts that have a lot of stress, this material really comes in handy.
The problem for entry level printers is that you most likely will have to replace the heat brake with a high quality one made of titanium, yet doing that modification is actually pretty easy, if you get it for a new printer that you haven't even used, its even easier.
Still most /k/ stuff that has been 3d printed just uses PLA+ and it works almost flawlessly if there was no printing issues, besides PLA+ is much more available to buy and more cost effective if you buy in bulks.

Check out CHEP's Filament Friday channel, that helped me a lot, and if you have a Creality its a godsend

You can cast your stamping molds using lost PLA is what I'm saying. Aluminum may not last long when used for stamping steel sheets into flats, but I feel it'd last longer than printed plastic. That way, yes, you have to cast once, but once you're done casting and cleaning up your stamping dies using lost PLA, it's much more solid and likely to last you a long time compared to printing stamping dies all the time with PLA (which you really have to print near solid if not solid, are huge, take forever to print, etc). I've never tried either but I think you could make it work.

>After getting it in shape what is the best way to temper spring steel? Quench or no? I have asked around with some of my machinist buddies but gotten different answers, though none of them have made flat springs of firearm strength before
It depends on what exact alloy you're using. Most spring steels need to be quenched and then tempered, however, it's just a matter of whether an oil or water Q and what temps you hold it at.

>>56789472
>trying to solve the problem of attaching a barrel and gas system to a printed upper and not have it sag after heating up.
I still say we should be at least trying the Lewis GPMG route and making some brackets in the forend that hold cheap aluminum flashing from the hardware store as dissipators/radiators, plus a force-air cooling system that works off the remaining gas. It's certainly bulky and stupid, but even mounting a CPU fan ducted up under the forend and running off the same battery pack as his weapon light did a lot for one of my buddy's prototypes, dropped barrel temps by like 20-30°F in 10-round strings. He also had some luck by soldering on a couple of zinc CPU radiators to either side of the gas block, which is not much of a solution long-term (because of hte inevitable corrosion) but keeps it from sagging on a hot day and a couple mag dumps.

It's kind of the point, you learn best by doing challenging shit and fucking it up badly, not by playing with legos for an hour and wandering off. >fucking REEE someone explain why that design is so le genius
Greener's autococker? Count the number of parts. Count the number of spring. I say spring because there's only one (plus one farther back in the trigger). Look at what it's all actually doing in the gun, and how neatly it fits into the available space in the lockwork.
>A single part is the hammer, striker, sear, and cocking lever, with one pin and only four working surfaces
>the stud that lifts the cocking arm is also an out-of-battery safety AND part of the auto-ejection system
>one single, smooth action on five parts resets the trigger, cocks the hammer, and ejects the shells
>You can safely and easily decock the action by opening the gun and closing it with the trigger depressesed
>no exposed parts other than the ejector and trigger
>Those fucking voluptuous curves
It's UTTER FILTH. It's the difference between a program that does the work with sixteen interesting but isolated subroutines in a thousand lines of code and one that does the same job with fifty perfectly-crafted lines and a couple of arrays.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56812976
>>56812904
>depends on the metal, I think lead's ok to do that way because it melts so low
Technically yes, but if you're going for good detail, even in silicone, you really want a hot mold. Also, it's best practice to push pretty much anything you're casting in over 250°F to drive condensation out of the mold. Otherwise you can get blow-ups when it hits bubbles of water. In the best case you get micro-voids and worst-case it blows metal back up out of the funnel.
>t. garage caster who does lead and pewter minis, bullets, and some basic brass work

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56802757
With regards to the British in the early war I’d argue this was more of an issue of commanders. British troops were known for their professionalism and aggression and until the fall of France they were the only army in Europe to be fully mechanized. The Norwegian campaign was a joint French-British expedition that was essentially doomed to fail due to the lack of decisive moves by allied commanders, causing the beleaguered Norwegians to fight on their own until near the end. With regards to Crete the British had just evacuated Greece and were primarily concerned with theatre concerns like what to do with the evacuated troops and how to deal with events in North Africa. British troops in the fight for Crete were essentially ad-hoc and had limited resources with which to defend the whole island. An airborne assault was mostly unexpected as one of that scale had never been attempted before. Nevertheless the British soldiery was sufficient enough to convince the Germans to never attempt another major airborne operation. The German opinion of the British was positive during this period and the mistakes and gaps in equipment and doctrine were largely ironed out by late 1942. This period also saw the British development of the commando, the successful evacuation of Dunkirk (they still had to abandon several thousands in the rear guard and at Calais with the French), Arras, operation compass and crusader and the British and Soviet occupation of Iran. You also have to remember the British were also spread throughout the entire world, fighting in places as remote as Madagascar and Iraq while at war with the Germans.

Unironically the worst early war army factoring in its size was the red army. Just look at what happened in Barbarossa and Rhzev later on.

General Stilwell retreated from Burma with this personal staff, abandoning large portions of the Chinese X and Y forces, which were some of the best trained and equipped KMT troops they had. I don't think I know any pure military manga, but I've got some picks. My tastes are the less Japanese, the better
Holyland - street fighting
Historie - story of Eumenes, Alexander the Great's aide
Suicide island - Japan sends all it's suicidal peeps to an uninhabited island where they engage in tribal warfare. Villains tend to get away with too much, but the good bits are good enough for a try
Ajin - paranormal terrorists
Legend of the Galactic Heroes - Dated. Anime only. A pain to find sometimes, possibly on Youtube somewhere. The best space politics you'll ever see

There's multiple instances where that bodyguard chick should have been fucking riddled with bullets, but random cuts just show her gooning on the teams sent after them. I don't fucking care how good you are in combat, there is no realistic reason how someone should be able to cross a bare minimum 20 meters down a straight hallway with three shooters aiming for you and come out unscathed while wearing no body armor. But all of that pales to just how fucking retarded Koko is in her goal. Big spoilers ahead in case you give a fuck about this awful series, her goal is to stop war by closing off air travel. The idea is without the means of ease that air weaponry gives to warfare, people will just fighting. There's retard moment number one. Now, obviously people being people, they'll just rely on their navies and land based technology, if that happens her plan is to somehow make those not work too with I guess some fucking literal magic. What she's fucking idiotic about is all she would do is cause MORE war. Take away primarily logistical means by which other countries need to survive? You make desperate people, and desperate people will kill to survive. This entire series revolves around the circle jerk of anti-war but fails to bring about any meaningful message or conclusion to the series that doesn't end with the main characters looking like actual fucktards. Awesome, glad you read it, was one I recommended previous thread.

I'll recommend for something completely different and more broad historical fiction strategy "Altair: A Record of Battles"/Shoukoku no Altair. Fictional medieval war NotEurope NotCrusades setting, but a decent one. Zero magic shit, lots of awesome battles across the entire sphere of war and geopolitics. It's a vast Great War manga, so takes its time getting all the set pieces together and a few volumes to really rev up but the payoff is worth it IMO.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56783412
>Ad Astra: Scipio to Hannibal
Absolutely based taste, can't believe this is only mentioned once. Nearly perfect awesome manga rendition of the second punic wars. I think it got a little unfortunately rushed at the very end which was too bad, but forgivable given how good the rest was. Every single /k/ommando should read at least something on Scipio vs Hannibal and the Battle of Cannae and what came after. A lot of core strategies of the art of war echoed down from those battles for millennia sense, all new at the time, from terrain and envelopment usage to scorched earth logistical warfare and more. Author dramatizes and simplifies some aspects to fit in the manga but it's still damn good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So summary list of some less read ones:
>Groundless
This should be a gimme wtf. /k/ translated lots of this, it's a classic AU ww1 era type of militia scale civil war manga.
>Front Mission
As OP said, while it's mecha it's still great and also about as "realistic" as mecha gets.
>Ad Astra: Scipio to Hannibal
Awesome historical war adaption.
>Shoukoku no Altair
AU historical fiction, but pretty hard fiction in terms of weapons and strategies. No magic, no super tech, lots of great fighting, strategy that is indeed strategy, critical medieval fighting things like seige warfare, supply chains matter, leaders are both brilliant and fuckup in amusing ways. Certainly there is dramatization but it's good.
>Biomega/Knights of Sidonia
I honestly don't know if I'd call Blame that /k/, the other two are much more about the weapons and combat. But while pure advanced sci-fi they're still fun, KoS gets special mention for one of the few that really deals to some extent with fighting under pure STL conditions, having to worry about inertia and resources in space combat, the problems of acceleration, etc. Granted they grow enough by the end it gets more classic jap silly.
>Youjo Senki
It's about WW1/WW2 with limited magic, but the weapons and regular war are the core part and it plays with the expected typical tropes because in the end individuals CAN'T actually win a great war on their own. Nor even militaries if the politics isn't capable too. Even with the magic silliness the love of big guns and military and logistics is great. Also, Second Reich had best uniforms. Fight me.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56804624
>What is your emergency contingency place? How will you survive various emergency situations?
That depends on if the state/feds/someone else is going to working to restore order within a few days. If not, you're looking at a serious natural or man made disaster that you should be evacuating from. And yes, that's including the vast majority of people who aren't prepared for such a situation who will start to panic if no one is working to restore order as a serious disaster.

If someone is showing up to work to restore order, then either continue with my normal life if possible, volunteer to help, or get comfy at home while they do their thing.

For long term hardships like real hyperinflation, Great Depression 2, or similar, stock up on the luxuries you enjoy that would cease to be available to help keep up morale. Any event where stocking up on basic needs would be an issue would end up back in the serious natural or man made disaster category that you should be evacuating from. Anything else isn't worth prepping for.

Share and trade with others as much as possible, establish peaceful relations as soon as possible so we can make use of whatever limited resources we have to produce what we can and establish a viable zone of control.

After Armageddon if Im lucky I might just survive, but so help me God my family and community will thrive because of what I do. Anything mortal that'd like to challenge that can argue with 30-06.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56804624
My family used to own half of all the market gardens in my city until the 90's when they sold them and moved out to the country to go large scale. When COVID lockdowns were looking pretty fucking grim, I just went 4x4ing to avoid main roads that were being blocked and called my grandpa to let him know I was taking up living in the walled property at the rear of a block his earthmover rental business sat on, not far from his property. Back then I'd just installed the basics like a solar and generator system, groundwater pump and purifier, rain catchment and food stores, but he left the property to me in his will and I've expanded it since. Sadly I can't spend enough time there to keep a constant rotation of crops, but I have the space, equipment and massive stockpiles for rapid germination and high-yield growth for any time of the year.

COVID was a pretty excellent dry-run for determining timing and preparedness, as well as a reality check for just how authoritarian the government could become in such a short time, as well as the amount of materiel needed to get myself up and running. It also demonstrated that even concerted law enforcement searches couldn't locate me, as a neighbour snitched that someone had driven onto the property, in violation of lockdown rules, and yet after 4 attempts to navigate the property, they still came no where near finding me. Unfortunately, I have a girlfriend and kid now, so all my planning and practice will be insufficient if the time does actually come.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56811920
A real life apocalypse scenario won't be le based battle royale, like the video games and movies depict. Cormac McCarthy had the right idea.
It will be a miserable, soul-crushing slog. You won't be some sort of based post-apocalypse warlord. If you're to survive for any length of time, you will be a wretched half-feral creature, doing things that will haunt you to continue an existence that hates you.
Your greatest enemy will not be raiders or ZOG blue helmets or anything nearly quite so exciting and morally justifiable to kill.
You will be fighting other, equally desperate individuals, maybe people with families they need to provide for; that sort of thing.
You the kind of guy to take a unarmed families last bit of food at gunpoint to sustain your existence?
But then, people won't be your main problem.
Natural will.
One overhunted by a few dozen million people who had the same idea you did.
Infections, weather, yada yada. Turns out theres a lot of things that can kill you innawoods.
I suppose in a manner of speaking, dying of severe dysentery could be interpreted as "Leaving this existence with the biggest firework possible"

>>56811823
No. The hague and geneva conventions are actually quite specific in their scope, but there's other UN bodies that speak about advanced and upcoming weapons. The main topic on AI is the "man in the loop" aspect, and most nations with automated systems stop short of letting the AI just go vidyagame turret and pick its own targets. So you can be assured that in 2035 when the army is flying manhacks or something, there is some guy in a trailer in texas who tagged someone in the ME or something and clicked the "kill" button and let the machine take it from there.

Yes it's worth it. Just don't set your expectations of sound reduction too high, they don't sound like the movies.

Do check out the Obsidian it's a great option but also check out the other mainstream options like SilencerCo, AAC, Gemtech and Dead Air. Even the off-brands are worth a look like CGS, YHM, Thunderbeast, Griffin and OSS.

Also imo bespoke calibers are a must. If you want 9mm get 9mm, if you want .45 get .45 etc. And a dedicated .22 is super fun!

Oh one more thing
>OSS
They're "HUXWRX" now and are still some of the best most versatile cans out there for both rifles and handguns. Their 9mm can is quite good. Their rifle cans aren't the absolute quietest, but they have very low back pressure combined with very solid performance and that means they'll work on systems that don't have full fat adjustable gas blocks. Classic "top performing" answers like CGS (I've got a Hyperion) or more recently Diligent Defense, Otter etc, duke it out for best suppression technically but they have very high back pressure so they really NEED a platform that is specifically can friendly.

>Forget the $200 tax, what the fuck is up with the price of suppressors? They're just sealed tubes of steel with some baffles. What justifies one to cost up to and over $1k? If suppressors were deregulated would prices start dropping like a rock?
Well, first they aren't actually "just sealed tubes of steel". The high end ones these days are 3D printed Titanium or Inconel, or if steel it's still serious alloys and still at least has a lot of CNC. The tolerances are tight. But basically it comes down to the tax and wait. If it was just over the counter tax free, yes there'd be $50-100 ones. They'd perform worse and have a typical "breaks buy a new one" like anything else, but that'd be ok for most of the market.

But if you have to wait a fucking year, and have a $200 minimum floor, it better be fucking worth it. And you probably want it to last forever. So the American market has skewed towards ekeing out every last little bit of performance. Fancy QD mounts to enable rapid swapping between a variety of firearms. Solid gold plated warranties, where so long as the serial number is still intact they'll repair fucking anything. The good places will flat out take care of you (once) for free if you fuck up and misalign the thing and then shoot a round right into it ("baffle strike"). And they'll still repair it for a low price if you do it again and again. It's like an enterprise class warranty contract on a computer, you can get spendy real fast if you start going for advanced replacement 24/7 service type of stuff.

So that's where the money goes in our fucked up by government warped market. You can go look at a bunch of countries in Europe of all places and see what it might be like normally, and yes it'd be 10x cheaper. Some people would still want the best but most would pick cheap.

>>56797581
A gravity damn relies on the weight of the dam to resist both uplift pressure and the mass of the water it’s holding back. Ignoring all the corncob concrete retards, there is a very real problem gravity dams face if the sudden mass of water or uplift pressure suddenly becomes more than the mass of the dam. This can occur just from natural erosion of the mass of concrete over time or even a sudden spike in water mass due to global warming.
Basically, since we are already seeing a spike in water mass, and likely uplift pressures, you would really only need to reduce the mass/weight of the concrete slightly to cause a catastrophic failure at this point. Definitely not one bomb could be enough but you probably could get away with two well placed cruise missiles, like the LRASM to do enough initial mass removal to which water pressure would take care of the rest exploiting the weakened structure. Eventually the gravity dam would fail just by the matter of it having les weight than is required to gold the water.
https://www.civilengineeringweb.com/2020/10/forces-acting-on-gravity-dam.html#Forces_acting_on_gravity_dam

China massive flood update: Three Gorges Dam ‘leaked, moved and distorted but safe’
Beijing has admitted in a rare revelation that ts 2.4-kilometer Three Gorges Dam spanning the Yangtze River in Hubei province “deformed slightly”, with some nonstructural, peripheral parts of the dam had buckled, after record flooding.According to China Three Gorges Corporatoin, the dam’s deformation occurred last Saturday when flood from western provinces including Sichuan and Chongqing along the upper reaches of the Yangtze River peaked at a record-setting 61,000 cubic meters per second.

“The dam had ‘deformed slightly,’ displacing some external structures, and seepage into the main outlet walls had also been reported throughout the 18 hours on Saturday and Sunday when water was discharged though its outlets”, the corporation notes.

But the problem of water seeping out did not last long, as the dam reportedly deployed floodgates to hold as much water as possible in its 39.3 billion-cubic-meter reservoir to shield the cities downstream from the biggest Yangtze deluge so far this year.https://vietnamtimes.org.vn/china-massive-flood-update-three-gorges-dam-leaked-moved-and-distorted-but-safe-22646.html

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56807419
Chinese engineers and mechanics experts on Tuesday denounced the reports, saying the reports were taken out of context and exposed their anti-China mindset and lack of basic physics knowledge, Global Times said.

Accordingly, the engineers noted all objects subjected to force, including dams, roads and bridges, will display displacement and deformation to a certain extent. The elastic deformation is recoverable and not permanent, and that of the Three Gorges Dam has always been within the design limits.

The deformation smear also emerged in the summer of 2019 when the dam was holding floodwaters during China's rainy season. Chinese experts explained at the time that the dam was not on the edge of collapsing, and only had elastic deformation within the designed limits of about 1.4 to 26.7 millimeters.

Another slander in July 2019 cited satellite images of Google Maps showing the Three Gorges Dam "seriously distorted." Though the "distortion" later proved to be caused by low resolution of the image, the "deformation and collapse prediction" continued to circulate.

posts.com: Did some more Rustoleum night vision testing. Completely kills the shine from cheaper non IRR compliant materials after 12 hours of drying. For example I was able to kill the shine on the back hand parts of some Mechanix gloves with a coat of matte ultra gray. I would argue that IRR compatibility and ensuring you don't glow if someone flashes your position with a Vampire is even more important if you don't have nods as you wouldn't be able to just see and possibly pop someone flashing IR at you and anyone messing with non visible flashlights is likely looking for you with nods and will see you way before you see them if your IR signature is super bright in a dark setting.

Update on ye old PSA Blem, ran the first 90 rounds through it and 5 had light primer strikes. Confirmed it wasn't ammo as it is IMI and Lake City M855/M193 full power. Second attempt to run them yielded 4/5 rounds firing with last one being a bit stubborn. Put in friends IWI AR and it went off.

Got to tinkering and found the blem inside the upper receiver underneath the BCG rails where the anodizing or coating failed and was rough. Scraped it down a little with a brass brush. Didn't look like it interfered with the BCG anyway. Further digging revealed I am dumb and put the hammer spring on incorrectly which is likely what caused the issue, so more testing will need to be conducted.

All that being said final result is almost identical to this, the midwest extended quad rail is super tough and I love it. The Romeo 7 is completely unremarkable which I think is good seeing no flaws. Dropped it and beat on it a couple times and held at 25yd zero.

I think last thing needed is a streamlight and we are off to the races for the brand new value beater. Pic rel is same build minus magpul stock for a b5 stock

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
more /pfg/ NIR proofing tests on paint so far
Rustoleum 2X Clearcoat: No reduction in IR reflection/glowing
Krylon Colormaxx Primer: Gray Primer, works and retains pattern under IR illum
Dupli-Color Auto Primer Sandable series: Red Oxide, works and retains pattern under IR illum
Krylon Specialty Camoflage Olive Green: Very good pattern retention and glow reduction, the best so far

Seems like the winning formula is matte/primer flat coats that occlude the original surface completely, with the specialty camo paint performing the best in terms of making the surface area dark. If you don't want a tactical painters smock of a mess all over your gear like mine you could always try color matching your gear, but for people who want to camo their gear and hide from night vision users it seems like most basic flat color spraypaints will assist in hiding your signature at night from IR floodlights. If you are good with stenciling you could really get a good night vision contrast camo on your gear that you can match to the local flora around you.

>>56815724
Ceramic composite plates functionally dont degrade when stored in a climate-controlled place like a house. Variable Armor for Troops, the OG Alumina/fiberglass plate from the mid-late 60s, still gets trotted out of storage and tested every decade or so, and it still works fine. The polyethylene component in plates is generally pressed and seems to avoid the majority of the temperature sensitivity loose polyethylene has (dont store Poly soft armor in your car trunk in fucking Arizona, please).

I am an agent of chaos, Ill throw my ill-advised recommend for low-cost armor for Blackbeard Protective Products Swimmer cut III+, right at 4lbs for a 10x11.6 medium. Purports to handle 7.62x39 BZ, 7.62x51 M61 AP and M80a1, M855a1. They list their component suppliers, Morgan Technical Ceramics for the B4C-SiC strike face, the grade of Dyneema they use (hb-26 and HB-210). When I get a job again im buying a pair for shits, and another pair to flip Buffman's way if he wants em to test. If they shake out they beat the dick off everything at the price point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I saw this in the last thread and thought I'd add some suggestions to it.

Frankly I'd just get the standard 4800 for most purposes, 0.2 lb really isn't a big price to pay for added drop protection and reduced BFD. I get that BFD isn't likely to be a big deal but it's certainly better if bullets cause less injury rather than more.

Another thing, we don't know how well 4800s perform against above-level IV threats yet. IMO .300 Win Mag M2 AP protection is good insurance as the 6.8x51 general issue round may be more potent than standard NIJ-level M2 AP. Or it may not, it's quite possible it's actually less potent, but without knowing in advance it's better to err on the side of safety.

It's possible the LTC 26300 could stop higher level threats than the 4800 if it's using equally good materials and manufacture, though that's unknown right now. If that were the case, it could be a good middle ground between the 4800 and Colossus, as - bluntly stated - I think 6.8x51 general purpose should be the new baseline for plates.

The LTC 28601 offers a bit less weight for coverage than the Colossus does, at the expense of drop protection and no guarantee against threats significantly above .308 M993 grade. It's a pretty hard sell imo when it also costs like 4x as much, but may have appeal to some folks.

>>56817072
I dig the flowchart.
4800 vs 4800LV is personal preference, but if im dropping 1500 for a light level IV, I want the LIGHTEST level IV. No dropface protection = get gud and dont drop your shit, problem solved.
4800 doesnt seem to stop anything past 30-06 AP and 7.62x54r API, so pretty much steel-core .30cal. Not bad, it definitely hits the IV standard, but it WILL fall on its ass against tungsten stuff, its Boron carbide.
6.8 EPR will probably have the ege over 30-06 in sectional density, but it may end up not having the penetrator mass to do much with that advantage. B-32 and M2AP are both really optimal for steel-core loadings, maybe you could eke out another 15grains of penetrator by letting the core protrude like the new EPRs do, but thats splitting hairs.
LTC 26300 should have the same weakness as the Hesco 4800 to threats above 30-06 AP, specifically tungsten. Boron carbide is prone to shear amorphization under bigass loads like WC impacts, and it extremely underperforms. A 10mmthick sintered B4c tile with UHMWPE backing, ICW a soft armor insert, had the fololowing v50s against some threats: 943m/s against APM2, 1002m/s against B32, but only 598m/s against (tungsten core) FFV (M993)
I dont think it has any tricks up its sleeve against beefy stuff, the 26300.

>>56797408
Long recoil is in theory the most safe action available. It offers ample time for pressure to drop, allows the designer/engineer to use a heavy spring to manage recoil, and allows the locking system to experience force in a single predictable, repeatable direction.
Because of this you require less weight to meet saami proof pressure and can get away with a lighter weight firearm. It's not used a lot because it's more expensive, required more maintenance and is less accurate.

>>56806234
Yes you dummy. By making the barrel a moving component, it is no longer fixed in relation to the sights/scope. You now have another area of variability as the barrel resettles in a different position each time it cycles. You can engineer around it by having very very precise tolerances and small clearances, but why would you?

It's like pistols. Cheapo blowbacks have great out of the box precision by the simple virtue of the barrel being fixed in place. Short recoil guns have to be primped and made very tight to get to the same level of inherent precision.

>>56813626
Reciprocating mass does not cause recoil. What causes recoil is acceleration. High acceleration of high mass -> high recoil. Slow acceleration of low mass -> low recoil.

Now on the other hand, there is absolutely no reason this same recoil cannot me achieved with a conventional short stroke system. You just need a bolt whose momentum at the start of the stroke equals that of the bullet and then you'll have to decelerate it slowly ie. avoid slamming it into the back of the receiver.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56815501
Basically it goes like this:
Bullet:
0.004kg * 900 m/s = 3.6 kgm/s
BCG:
0.4kg * x = 3.6 kgm/s
x = 9 m/s
And it just happens that the AR15's bolt carrier velocity at the start, before the bolt has even opened, is close to 9 m/s which is why there is actually no/very little recoil impulse felt by the shooter at that moment.
Now the problem is when the bolt stops abruptly at the rear, that is a big jolt. A longer bolt travel or a stronger spring is required!
https://youtu.be/gD7pd03L43k

Best "mod" is getting a better frame and hip pad/belt. The standard ALICE frame is terrible because it has such drastic stand off from the body for some reason. If you have a medium you can use a MOLLE U-frame (unsure the correct model number) and it helps carry loads with much leverage on your back. The 365 micro is rated for P+ (which I'd probably not use, usually), but has 10, 12 & 15 round magazines, all of which are far more than sufficient for a compact SD weapon. If conceal & compact aren't a high priority, there are other options.

What I can tell you that slugs out of a regular shotgun are fine if you're in a hilly or wooded area with less sight line.

yeah, some hunting areas are shotgun only so no rifles, but people don't want to be limited to just buckshot if they plan to take larger game.
There are also fully rifled shotgun barrels or even half rifled ones for Japan. You can spot them by their rifle sights rather than beads and usually a rail for an optic.

Unpopular? It was a literal meme as "the world's most powerful rifle cartridge" for decades. Only reason you wouldn't have heard of it is if your gun knowledge came from movies or video games exclusively, because the gun press has been writing about that cartridge for a long ass time.
Anyway, read more about it and one of the other things it's infamous for is it's crazy high recoil, which is undoubtedly why it's not very popular. Look at the used market, these huge bores like .458 win are disproportionately cheap, just like huge meme revolvers a lot of people buy them, then regret it after shooting a handful of cartridges, then you see the gun for sale with a bunch of ammo.

The .30-.378 Weatherby is the much more interesting round which you probably haven't heard of either.

posts.name: Anonymous

>Why is .460 Weatherby so unpopular when it's so good
Because it's not actually good? Why the fuck would anyone want it? Crazy high recoil, like 5 fucking times 30-06, for what? If you're into ultra long range, something modern like .416 Barrett has much better BC, and the cost of reaching out to 1000-2000yd is high no matter what you're doing. 300wm will hunt anything in most of the world at ranges a lot farther then almost anyone should be ethically hunting while still being reasonably priced, available, good gun selection and being reasonable to handle. 308 will hunt anything at more reasonable range which is still longer then most people are capable of (or depending on where you live even have a safe shot at, in a lot of east coast dense woods you basically never have safe shots of even 300yd let alone 400-500. <200yd is where like 99% of hunting is done, if you can't get to within three to six hundred feet (and usually a lot less) of a dumb animal in the woods the problem is you.

It was one of the many "LE AFRICAN DANGEROUS GAME (you will never hunt and people hunted fine for a century before this)" cartridges made when that was cool and mainly let people brag about "the most powerful round!" with something they'd buy, shoot once and then never shoot again. >I want to shoot .45-70 JHPs that grenade themselves at 3k FPS
Alright, but that makes you one of us weirdos, just like liquid nitrogen overclockers. Which is fine particularly on /k/, normal people wouldn't ever come here and if they did they wouldn't stay. But it also shouldn't be any mystery to you why it's ultra niche as fuck. Which again is fine, lots of us are into things that are niche and have niche weird builds even for standard cartridges. Pic related is my 308 gun. I EDC a Maxim 9 in a shoulder holster I made myself. These are weird people choices.

>Cases are expensive but handloads can be made for the price of factory .500 S&W.
Which is almost 200cpr. I've seen basic bitch off the shelf 50bmg for near that in the last 6 months. And most people don't reload either which again is to your question of "why is this so unpopular". If the answer is "reloading is required" well you are right off the radar of 95% of the market.

Of course one of the core joys of reloading is precisely that you no longer really need to care what the market wants, you can do whatever purely for component costs. You don't save money reloading popular stuff factoring in time/equipment. You get to do unpopular stuff and really tune your loads exactly and then can do it repeatably. So unironically do what you find fun. I'm really interested in .375 raptor for example, I'm exploring practically the opposite of you, trying to figure out the best performing best suppressing subsonics I can. I wish it would take off as well and I'm kind of bummed the inferior (imo) 8.6bo has more steam instead. Such is life though. Do post vids of your fun explosions!

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56808746
I'm not sure about any real sources, I just know from hand loading friends that lathe-turned brass doesn't expand as well and will more easily blow out the sides when fired instead of expanding. It's not a problem with lower powder loads, but once you start going for the big loads you need drawn brass since it's far better at expanding instead of blowing out.

These problems really only regularly occur with big game rounds like these, you won't generally have issues with .308 or .223 unless you tried going for an extreme powder load something like +P+++

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56816607
>how much chance does a Apache have against russian SU's and MIG's?
Helos are prey for fast movers but only if they can be seen which is hard because they stay close to the ground and behind trees, buildings and hills. They're low enough that the curvature of the earth prevents long range detection.
Most SAMs can't effectively track anything that close to the ground. Flares will throw off IR tracking and radar is nearly useless. Missiles don't manoeuvrer so well at that altitude either, they have no ability to navigate obstacles also, typically they have complete freedom in three dimensions to intercept a target.

>how good can it survive the AA of the russians?
AA won't even see them unless they go high, which they don't need to in a combat scenario.
MANPADs are a danger but they're usually far enough or fast enough to make actually targetting them hard.

>>56817223
If these are being issued and are scattered on the battlefield, Yeah. I'd totally be about collecting half a dozen or more so I had a working pair and back-ups for parts. Would be fun to carefully tweak them with small mods to clean 'em up without destroying the overall aesthetic. Having them designed for regular use with "extreme" high pressure rounds would give me confidence to run P+ through them all day with no worries. Blowing one up isn't really my concern so much as how well they hold up to 10K or 20K rounds passing through them and what sort of wear & maintenance that entails.

I'd have a few questions about accuracy, performance, access to critical parts, etc. Would also want to know where I'd be getting a dozen reliable magazines. Once past those questions, it wouldn't be worth it if they turned up on the "war surplus" market for $1500 or $2K meme profiteering prices ... unless there was something extraordinary about them, be it accuracy, durability, reliability, etc.

Free as a plinker and home defense weapon? Absolutely. Cheap, like $300 or $500 cheap? Still interested depending on answers to the above questions. Over $500? Probably not, unless there was something extraordinary to change that calculus. Aesthetic and war trophy isn't "extraordinary." Enough.

I do like the look. I have big hands, so it looks comfy for me that way. I'd pay $50 to spend an afternoon on a range shooting 2 or 3 hundred rounds through it to see if I really liked it.
